output.text: What exactly is an aggressive investor?

tooltip.content: These investor types give a general guideline for your information. Your type may change over time as your needs and goals change.

Keep in mind that your investor type is not a description of you – it is a measure of your financial situation, personality and the timeframe you have to invest. The higher the returns you chase, the more you need to accept risk and run the chance that your investments will fluctuate in value, lose value or fail entirely.

items.text: Accepts extreme ups and downs in the value of their investments
Can achieve higher returns over the long term
Does not need regular income from their investments

What mix of investments suits an aggressive investor?

tooltip.content: These investment mixes are only a general guideline for your information. Your ideal investment mix may change over time as your needs and goals change.

output.text: To achieve the results you are looking for as an aggressive investor (the amount of money you get back and the ups and downs you experience), you’ll need a certain mix of various kinds of investments. For example, an aggressive investor might have:

tooltip.content: Investment experts call this mix your 'asset allocation'. Research shows that the right mix allows you to achieve the results you are looking for. Within each kind of investment, it is also a good idea to spread your money across different companies, industries and countries in order to smooth out the ups and downs. This is called 'diversification'.
Here cash means investing your money in things like a term deposit from a bank. To learn more about investing your money in bank deposits, see our bank deposits guide.
Investing in bonds means that you lend your money to a government or company and they pay you regular interest payments. To learn more about investing in bonds, see our bonds guide.

Most people's homes are not an investment, so here property means either putting money in managed funds that invest in commercial property or owning rental property. To learn more, see our property investing guide.

Investing in shares means that you buy a part of a company (a 'share') and receive part of the company's profit, either through dividends paid by the company or because the value of a company goes up. To learn more about investing in shares, see our shares guide.
